section.text: Great. Thanks so much. Just my question is really centered around Humira, and I know -- I appreciate some of the access commentary made at the beginning the call but are there any surprises so far in these discussions as we think about where either rebates or prices settling out for Humira? I'm really just trying to my hands around I think previously you've commented you expected U.S. Humira erosion to be down roughly 45% plus or minus 10% and just was wondering if that range holds given what you know today about the negotiations? And if I just do a quick follow -- a second question on immunology, I think it was a European JAK update out this morning and I just was wondering any impact do you expect to the Rinvoq franchise for that, just maybe some context about how relevant, I guess Europe was as part of the mix and does that label update kind of impact your outlook at all? Thanks so much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chris Schott", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "6a66b212-9b6f-4d56-8605-ff5301fd8da4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at J.P. Morgan"}

section.text: Okay. Chris this is Rick, I'll cover part of that question then I'll have Jeff fill in on any additional commentary around the contracting. I think first, if we talk about the 45% plus or minus 10%, that is the range that we gave, we're obviously working on doing the final forecasting for 2023. As we said in the past, there are two major components which will play into that forecast. One is, how will the biosimilars priced, that will certainly have some impact, we won't know that until we actually get into the market and start to see some of that activity. But the other big component is obviously our coverage, our access coverage for Humira and the position that Humira has on those formularies.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "f7b28846-8e4c-4fd0-8b0e-52e8cadc38b9", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: I would say that negotiating by Jeff's team is going very well. As I mentioned in my comments, we're about 80% of all covered lives now and I would expect that to rise to a level that's above 90% as we move towards the end of the year. Once we have a final number there, it will allow us to do the final modeling for 2023, and that's at the point where we'll be able to refine that 45% plus or minus 10%, but to tell you it's going on-track I would say there's no surprises and I'd say I feel good about how the negotiations are going. With all the major managed care organizations and PBMs. Jeff anything to add there?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "f7b28846-8e4c-4fd0-8b0e-52e8cadc38b9", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: No, just to just to confirm Rick that no real surprises in terms of where we've been. And as we've communicated before, our principles of coexisting over time with one or more biosimilars seems to be the way that the market will play out and certainly like we saw in Europe that we had the principle of for patient continuity to concede pricing to maintain that patient access. So, Chris no major surprises that we've seen so far.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "e86259e4-a538-4ac4-9c5e-67ca7b72b9e1", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: You want to talk about PRAC?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "6329e1fe-1048-4e30-92c8-e47cd82d8bd8", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Yeah, maybe I'll...
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "e2320e90-3b32-4a78-99c1-72989f79bf85", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Maybe Roopal can talk about PRAC.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "9de42e63-ed85-4d80-b598-14566176f430", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Maybe Roopal you could address the procedure and where we are in the procedure now, and I'll cover the commercial?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "3aa2c41c-e30e-455a-a386-54cca72a99fe", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Thanks, Jeff, I'll give some context. So, the next step here after PRAC would be moving to the CHMP here in November and then the European Commission should finalize this, so we expect December or January. So, PRAC completed their review and what we see in the labeling is update in warnings and this is related to outcomes of the ORAL Surveillance study. And in particular in Section 4.4 four which is warnings there is a list of subgroups that were found to be at-risk based on analysis from ORAL Surveillance, for example, patients greater than equal to the age of 65, those that are at risk for cardiac events, smokers for example, and in these patients the use of JAK inhibitors would be after a consideration of other therapies, if I'm paraphrasing, if no suitable alternatives. So, this is consistent with the practice of medicine, it provides specific guidance, and we would say pragmatic at this stage.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Roopal Thakkar", "section_number": 8, "uuid": "1fc72499-2465-4704-bfa8-c3ae18e5618a", "speaker_title": "Vice President of Global Regulatory Affairs and R&D Quality Assurance at AbbVie"}

section.text: Yeah, and Chris to that point, I mean this is largely consistent with what we see from ORAL Surveillance and the XELJANZ label which is widely sort of understood by the European physicians, and so to cut to the quick, we don't anticipate a material impact as this continues through the process.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 9, "uuid": "d3c1723a-1068-4d51-bc22-192d62e33cee", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Thanks Chris. Operator next question please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Shea", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "bbf0b04a-6944-4d11-943a-4102ca9ec74e", "speaker_title": "Vice President, Investor Relations at AbbVie"}

section.text: Thank you. I was under the impression that we give more granularity on Humira erosion this quarter, and you're saying that's really going to come in Q4, so I'm wondering did I kind of not hear right before or does something changed? And then second question is just on contracting in general, my understanding is that payor contracts, they're really not rock solid, they can be reopened when there's a change in the marketplace on things like pricing, in this case of biosimilars so when we do kind of get whatever next level of guidance we get from you, isn't that going to continue to remain fluid, because market dynamics all play-out as of January, we'll get to mid next year, you'll get more and hence you'll know pricing better and that sort of thing? Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Tim Anderson", "section_number": 12, "uuid": "20b06c6b-6622-42d4-be96-5e3358c9cf3c", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: Yeah, Tim this is Rick, I'll cover that one. So. I think we've talked a number of times on these calls about what we would project in the third quarter call, and I believe what we said is that we will ultimately provide you an update on where we were in the process. And so that's what we attempted to do. I can't give you a number for 2023 until I know what the total access is and not all those contracts are done yet. They're proceeding well, so I feel good about that, but until we actually know that the contract is solid, and we know what that access looks like we can't give you an accurate projection. And I understand the desire by the investment community to understand what that number is, but I think you probably also understand that we want to give you the most accurate number that we can give you, and we don't want to give you a number that's not accurate. And so, it is going to require us until we get to the fourth quarter call to provide that for you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 13, "uuid": "93068c2d-6a23-4ae6-94a9-21a086f560d5", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: You are correct in a sense about the way you described how these contracts work. They can be reopened at some point in time, I wouldn't say that's all that common, usually and in particular I'd say around this kind of a situation you're going to anticipate what you think is going to happen in the second half of the year and try to position the contract in a way that it can ultimately deal with those changes going forward, but you are correct to say that they could reopen a contract if they chose to do that. There are various kinds of contracts that we use in some cases there are penalties or repercussions that would have to come into consideration if a contract got reopened at some point in time, they're not all like that, but many are like that. So, it varies, and I'd say generally speaking, your concept is valid, but I would say it's probably a little less fluid than the way you necessarily described it, particularly in this environment where we know there will be a number of biosimilars coming in, so you anticipate that we've built the contracts around that set of assumptions. Jeff, anything you want to add?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 13, "uuid": "93068c2d-6a23-4ae6-94a9-21a086f560d5", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: No, I think Tim Rick described it in the right way, while there are typically -- they are typically all clauses based on timing or other dynamics, I think one of the considerations is obviously as we've highlighted before, most of the biosimilars are going to be coming in the second half of the year. So, to some degree that actually limits if it was a rare case, and they typically are rare where a contract is blown up or renegotiated in the middle of the year, that length of time that's left in '23 for some of those payers to let's take a negative action, put some natural constraint on them in terms of when they would time that out, but Rick highlighted it very nicely in terms of the dynamics.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "07573f2f-1b9d-4c9d-9381-d3172bd5cda7", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Thanks Tim. Operator, next question, please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Shea", "section_number": 15, "uuid": "a5badb66-51b5-4123-9075-2bce337937ca", "speaker_title": "Vice President, Investor Relations at AbbVie"}

section.text: Great. Thanks for taking my question. And maybe one more question on the contracting side. Could you help us understand if the pricing part of the contracts is something that you have a good handle on at this point? And then a follow-up question is that how do you think about the cadence of BD activity once you hit the mark of less than 2 times leverage by end of the year? Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Mohit Bansal", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "2301d888-5d91-4104-ae5d-ae33b5da62b4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Jeff, you want to cover that?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 18, "uuid": "990c4c89-761d-44dd-bf7a-6f6e7a07401a", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Yeah. So, look in terms of what Rick had highlighted in terms of our confidence in projecting the 80%, obviously there is a couple of components to that. So, we have, while all the contracts aren't fully complete, with the ones that we've done, we've done some significant modeling work to understand if we're retaining the ability to stay on the formulary, we would model our volume like how much would we retain versus would go to one or more biosimilars, that's something that we can understand, and we have made base case both first half and second half pricing assumptions based on those contracts. Now what's been highlighted in the last couple of questions is there is still uncertainty on the rest of the contracts that are yet to have been secured, and also a bit on that second half price dynamics. So, those are the elements that are going to give us more confidence as we go to the fourth quarter call to give everyone a secure number for next year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 19, "uuid": "9d0c70e8-6330-4907-b96b-8f2c55e56fd0", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: This is Rick, I'll cover your business development question. I think if I step-back and look at where are we today, we have been for the last several years operating with an approach roughly $2 billion to add incremental pieces to the business. We've effectively used that over the last several years to be able to build some additional, particularly, I'd say early-stage pipeline, as at to the company. We're continuing on that same approach right now. Now, having said that, we obviously have paid down debt very rapidly, we will be in a position where if we chose to do something we could do something. I'd say if I look at the business today and I look at how it's performing around the expectations that we had for the business going forward, I'd say there is no need for us to be able to do anything in that area.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "10fde273-3222-41a8-8018-811e39e0cdc7", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: And I go back to the original premise of what we described to the investment community of what we believe would happen when biosimilars entered the U.S. market for Humira, what we said was, that we believe the bulk of the erosion would occur in 2023, some additional erosion in 2024 and '25 and beyond, we would return to a significant growth, we'd be able to deliver high single digit growth from that point forward through the end of the decade, that's what we said. Everything I know about the business today would suggest to me that we are able to do just that and we're confident that we're able to do that with the portfolio we have and the late-stage pipeline and additional indications that we have coming forward.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "10fde273-3222-41a8-8018-811e39e0cdc7", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Having said that, I can also tell you that over the last 10 years we've demonstrated to ourselves and hopefully to you that we can acquire businesses and assets and we can integrate those, and we can successfully drive those. And so, if we found something that we thought was very important to add to the business, we certainly have the financial wherewithal, and this business has tremendous cash flow, we could do that. I can tell you we don't see that right now, so I wouldn't assume that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "10fde273-3222-41a8-8018-811e39e0cdc7", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: And the other thing I'd point out is, as an example, the most important thing I know everyone is focused what that erosion herd is going to look like including us, to be honest, that I know why, but probably the single most important thing for us going forward is to hit what I described to you a moment ago is that underlying non-Humira business growing at a rate that can drive those expectations. And that's key and I would say there's two factors that are most important around that. The first is, that Skyrizi and Rinvoq grow fast enough that they can more than offset that they can essentially grow through all of the erosion that occurs on Humira and deliver incremental performance above and beyond that. And I feel highly confident in that, I mean you can look at the trajectories of those assets now and you really phase we're in right now in IBD and PsA, I would say I have got very high level of confidence that they will perform at that level or well above that level.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "10fde273-3222-41a8-8018-811e39e0cdc7", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: And the second thing is, all the other growth assets, they have to be growing fast enough that they can get us to be able to grow at that rate that I described. And if you take this quarter as an example, and you look at the business without Humira, the underlying growth is about 6.5% and remember that 6.5% is absorbing the economic impact we see the Aesthetics business in the market and competitive dynamics that you see in Imbruvica. So that tells you that underlying growth is pretty strong. And so, I think those the important things that investors have to focus on, and the erosion is certainly one of those and I'll essentially go back to Jeff and all, when are you going to hit trough earnings and I'll recognize that and that's why I wanted to provide you some assurance of what that trough earnings is going to look like.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 5, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "10fde273-3222-41a8-8018-811e39e0cdc7", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Thanks Mohit. Operator, next question please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Shea", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "9987ebb3-4215-458e-9a0f-82ca24184b14", "speaker_title": "Vice President, Investor Relations at AbbVie"}

section.text: Hi, thanks for taking the questions. Maybe two for me. Rick, I appreciate your comments on 2023 and the Aesthetics business. I know you don't want to give guidance, but I guess at a high-level, do you think you can grow that franchise next year versus this year? And then on Epcoritamab, congratulations on the filing there, just wondering what you're expecting regarding the requirement for inpatient administration, J&J recently got approval of their bispecific in myeloma, and it looks like there is a requirement there for inpatient administration of the drug during the step-up period. So, just wondering how we should think about inpatient versus outpatient dosing of Epco? Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Terence Flynn", "section_number": 23, "uuid": "1e2e7de0-4cfa-492f-ac4f-791b24e75f8d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Okay. Excellent. Thanks Terence. I'll cover the first one. So, if I look at the Aesthetics business, we're clearly seeing this economic pressure in the U.S. and I would expect that we will see that to continue into 2023, certainly, it's difficult to predict what will happen in the U.S., will it get worse, will we go into a recession, will it stay about the same, I'd say we're looking at this extremely carefully. The good news right now I would say is that the factors that we're looking at that seem to be driving this consumer confidence and behavior the most in the U.S. appear to have stabilized at the levels that they are at. And so. I would say that's a positive thing. Now it's fluid, because obviously if the economic situation got worse in the U.S. my guess is it will trend down again. But at least it appears right now that they've stabilized and maybe even ticked up just a little bit. Meaning moved in a positive direction just a little bit.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 24, "uuid": "94f6c94e-b93f-4082-9514-fbe1401d997f", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: I think it's very difficult to predict, here's what I would assume. I would assume that a significant part of '23 we will have an impact on. Now also recognize that we saw this phenomenon as we said in the last call start in May, we weren't sure at the time whether it was the summer season starting a month early or it was the economic impact because we have been watching the indicators and they trend down several months ahead of that, but we didn't see an impact until the month of May. So, the point is, when we hit May and beyond, we're going to be lapping the impact so the negative impact will be softened on the business, so we'll return to better growth rates no matter what just mathematically, right? But I think the best prediction we can have is, it's going to have an impact in a good part of '23. I think it's the best way for us to think about it. Now, again, the rest of the business has an opportunity to be able to offset that as we saw in this quarter.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 24, "uuid": "94f6c94e-b93f-4082-9514-fbe1401d997f", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: And this is Rob. I would just add, if you think about more long-term, if you think about what happened in '08 and '09, the business declined high single-digits and then we saw after that very robust growth in the mid-teens in the next decade. So, given that penetration rates are still very low today, there's clear ample opportunity to grow this market. I think once you get on the other side of the economic impact which we expect to be transient, we still expect businesses to deliver long-term growth as Rick highlighted earlier, we're still on-track for that long term high-single-digit growth getting to greater than $9 billion for 2029, so we'll have to navigate obviously the short-term economic impact, but we still have tremendous confidence in the long-term outlook for Aesthetics.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert A. Michael", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "c1fb8bd9-8c9c-47bd-88c4-d13ff7048240", "speaker_title": "Vice Chairman and President at AbbVie"}

section.text: For Epco?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 26, "uuid": "534512b2-20b9-46c9-8c68-3e0c77f436c0", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Hey. This is Neil Gallaher. I'll take the Epco question. So, the first thing, I just want to caution, put a word of caution before I answer your question directly around inpatient stay, which is that the patient population that our competitor studied with the BCMA x CD through is quite different in terms of overall benefit risk. So, the indication that was granted was in fifth line plus multiple myeloma, which is very heavily pre-treated in frail population. So, to extrapolate any interpretation of benefit risk from that population into the relapsed/refractory DLBCL population that we have studied and filed for with Epcoritamab would not be valid, so just a word of caution there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Neil Gallagher", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "fb62cf54-9a8c-4887-83e0-f8b07781b383", "speaker_title": "Vice President of Development and Chief Medical Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: That said, the study that we have filed had required for 24-hour patient today, one overnight stay, however in subsequent studies we are aiming to remove that requirement so patients would not be required to remain overnight. And we do believe because of the emergence and stable overall benefit risk for Epcoritamab a couple of things that we believe that it has the potential to be best-in-class, we also believe that our strategy to remove overnight stays as is very valid and a reasonable one to proceed. Hope that answers your question.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Neil Gallagher", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "fb62cf54-9a8c-4887-83e0-f8b07781b383", "speaker_title": "Vice President of Development and Chief Medical Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Thanks Terence. Operator, next question please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Shea", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "489a462d-245f-46be-a503-bcd6d5abed14", "speaker_title": "Vice President, Investor Relations at AbbVie"}

section.text: Thank you. A couple of questions please. First on Imbruvica, I'm assuming that Imbruvica is going to be included in the top 10 CMS list for price negotiation on the Medicare next year. I'm assuming that's correct, when we think about the impact on net pricing for Imbruvica, do you anticipate net pricing coming under pressure throughout 2026 given the contracting that's expecting to take place among your competitors to secure formally positions given the catastrophic coverage burden on PBMs post the IRA implementation. So, is the impact going to get put forward for the class including for Imbruvica before you actually get the price cut coming?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Baum", "section_number": 30, "uuid": "5c1d7ca9-3211-4da1-a70f-aaddcfc33ab0", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup"}

section.text: And then second, with Epcoritamab, there has been some interesting data on the importance a profound T-cell depletion in lupus using CAR-T assets, and CD20 bispecific could get to a similar level. I'm wondering whether you have interest in pivoting Epcoritamab and exploring in refractory lupus as one of your competitors already has, particularly given you have a subcu administration which obviously have some advantages? Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Andrew Baum", "section_number": 30, "uuid": "5c1d7ca9-3211-4da1-a70f-aaddcfc33ab0", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup"}

section.text: Yeah, hi Andrew, it's Jeff, I'll take I'll take your first question. So, when we -- obviously, we're still studying very carefully the IRA, and you know we're also discussing directly with CMS, not just through pharma, but our own company in terms of how they're going to basically select the different drugs that will be negotiated and that's a little bit unclear at this point. It's not unreasonable based on the size of Imbruvica to suspect it will be one of the earlier drugs that could potentially be negotiated, so just to just to clear that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "a14dd784-8393-4896-ab34-2499e7a9e347", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: In terms of what may take place before that potential negotiation in 2026, I would expect to see some modest changes in rebating, we see very small levels at this point now, but we do have a third competitor coming. So that would be something that we would continue to plan for as we move into that potential event.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "a14dd784-8393-4896-ab34-2499e7a9e347", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: This is Tom, maybe I'll answer the lupus question. First, I'll say it's actually, we're very exciting to see that paper showing that B-cell depletion can actually put patients with very severe lupus in remission. It's a very small study, some five patients, but everyone is looking at this as even with the surprise because we used to think we had to affect many mechanisms in lupus so that was one of the reasons it's so difficult. I used to be part of the Lupus Clinic in Montreal, so I know the charges with patients, so what we're looking at right now is we're asking, yes, the answer to your question is, can we use our existing assets and collaborations to see if we can do B-cell depletion as a treatment for lupus, the answer is yes, and the several questions we're asking ourselves is do we have to have as deeper depletion as we have with in hem-malignancies, nobody knows the answer, that might be important because if you have to have a very deep depletion it might be restricted more to more severe patients.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas J. Hudson", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "ed649d30-478c-486d-8971-bd653ef00f95", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President, R&D, and Chief Scientific Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: And again, that would be an advantage, but if he want to go to all lupus patients, because not all lupus patients are flaring all the time, the majority have a normal life, go to the clinic once a year and just see the physicians when they have flares. So, going to a very deep regimen for B-cell depletion might be deem too severe. So, the question is, yes, we're looking at it and trying to figure out what's the right regimen and how to approach that in lupus is very exciting questions which we're obviously looking into.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Thomas J. Hudson", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "ed649d30-478c-486d-8971-bd653ef00f95", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President, R&D, and Chief Scientific Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Thanks Andrew. Operator, next question please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Shea", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "f8f6a83a-939f-4f9f-9b7b-0e3f53258c40", "speaker_title": "Vice President, Investor Relations at AbbVie"}

section.text: Thank you. What is your level of confidence in a positive outcome for Vraylar in MDD at the end of the year? I imagine the review is well along, so you probably have good visibility, so for instance, a labeling discussion is underway, is the sales force being trained, etc. This is a very large opportunity that does not seem to be a point of external focus as far as I can tell, so I'm wondering what you could tell us about how things are going? Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steve Scala", "section_number": 35, "uuid": "b7542a39-d258-4414-9ad3-78a849537ddf", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen"}

section.text: Roopal?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 36, "uuid": "5a968ee4-fca3-470d-a272-f8d420039ba0", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Hi, it's Roopal. Thanks for the question. Maybe I'll go and then Jeff can talk about the opportunity. You're correct, the review is proceeding per our expectations. We have two positive studies in the space, and recall we also have the same endpoint, the depression endpoint that's read-out in three other bipolar depression studies that are already within label. So, there's quite a bit of evidence that's already been generated that's in front of the agency now. So, I would say it's proceeding well, and we still anticipate a decision by year-end. And I'll pass it to Jeff.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Roopal Thakkar", "section_number": 37, "uuid": "10d0ead3-0625-4fec-84da-ffcb66769bce", "speaker_title": "Vice President of Global Regulatory Affairs and R&D Quality Assurance at AbbVie"}

section.text: Yeah, Steve, and just in terms of your sales force question, I mean, we are very encouraged and excited about this potential approval. I mean, obviously, we continue to gain share week-by-week sequentially for our base indication, the bipolar indications, and we know that based on the profile that we have with Vraylar, so very, very strong efficacy, proven efficacy, a very good tolerability profile for an antipsychotic, no material weight gain, low metabolic effects, and I think importantly maybe not as appreciated, so there is no titration, you have a very simple starting dose of 1.5 milligram. So, as we do our research, we see that that profile is very strong as this potential add-on therapy in depression. In the last decade, there has been only one drug that's been approved for this indication and that's REXULTI, and we think -- that's a branded drug obviously, and we think we can compete very, very well. So, we have a big existing sales force and infrastructure, we are gearing up in terms of training, we have the established relationships across the big primary-care doctors as well as the psychiatrists, so we agree with your approach that a meaningful commercial opportunity that could evolve very quickly here once we get the approval.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "77774467-0074-43a6-aa0d-2ded273ea220", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Thanks Steve. Operator, next question please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Shea", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "bfae55e3-99ff-4cc8-bee3-bf9ee8274e3d", "speaker_title": "Vice President, Investor Relations at AbbVie"}

section.text: Thanks. Good morning. First, could you just provide some more color on how much of a benefit you're seeing for Skyrizi and Rinvoq in IBD, as you've been spending more time with the GIs and have your outlooks changed on the potential there as major contributors to the long-term growth for those franchises, so where are both of those being used in the treatment paradigms for the respective indications in Crohn's and ulcerative colitis? So that's one. And then secondly, just opex came in much lower than we expected, it seems to be getting better operating leverage from what you originally guided, are there areas where you scale back in spending whether in Aesthetics or HemOnc, there's pressures there, and how will you be thinking about that into the Humira LOE next year, so how much additional flexibility might you have on the spending side? Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gary Nachman", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "dc50ab30-0ff9-468b-9d63-4bcfaf028f8e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at BMO Capital Markets"}

section.text: Jeff?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "29bbc015-604a-4971-b4d7-324b24bc8d21", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Yeah. I'll take the IBD question. I think we've mentioned before, the IBD has been a very important part of our long-range plan, and when we gave the 2025 guidance, it looks relatively small because they're just ramping now. I would say that as AbbVie, we are very, very encouraged as I mentioned in my prepared remarks on the launch, and maybe I'll start with what we're hearing from the gastroenterologists. I think first is, they look at both assets and the global guidelines, the impressions and the clinical approach that we hear from the top leaders and also the community gastros is this idea over, I have to start to think about endoscopic healing, higher basically rates of efficacy and more significant clarity on what it's doing in the bowel versus just symptoms. And that seems straightforward, but we see the market moving very, very fast there in terms of understanding, and that's what we can deliver, whether it's the Skyrizi data on the endoscopic healing rates with a very, very convenient and strong safety profile or similar on the Rinvoq side in second line -- in the U.S. second line for patients that aren't doing well in UC. So, we see rapid adoption already as I mentioned that in the Rinvoq in the United States will be a second line plus based on the label, and we see very, very fast adoption. I'll give you some color on it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "2c595fb0-a403-468c-9e7d-97e6818b91e2", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: XELJANZ had been approved and is approved in UC in the United States, but basically it had very low adoption, we're seeing now in the community that 70% of the prescriptions are coming from physicians that have never written a JAK before, so it shows you that the clinical profile of Rinvoq in terms of its speed and the depth of the response is being viewed very, very well. So, not only is that encouraging for Rinvoq, you see, as I mentioned we're going to have the approval for Crohn's for Rinvoq in later lines next year as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "2c595fb0-a403-468c-9e7d-97e6818b91e2", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Skyrizi continues to surprise us to the upside, as you've heard from the call today. This is viewed increasingly as the preferred frontline drug coming straight out of the gate for Crohn's in the U.S. And the qualitative data that we're starting to see, and we are seeing some quantitative data that looks very strong to is that this is viewed as already as a best-in class product for Crohn's which is a very, very substantial market. So, we are very encouraged, we continue to say that the IBD is probably under-appreciated, and we'll continue to give updates as these launches progress.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "2c595fb0-a403-468c-9e7d-97e6818b91e2", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: So, Gary, this is Rob, I'll take your question on opex. If you look at the benefit, we're seeing about half it is actually coming from the stronger U.S. dollars, so it's more of an FX impact. The other half is spend, productivity, we always look for opportunities to drive more productivity in our spend, it's not so much about scaling back in parts of the business, we always look for ways to spend better, buy better and ultimately that helps us in many cases also over the long-term redeploy that investment to drive growth. As you think about '23, I've said given that 46% to 47% operating margin, directional input, I've also said, we're not going to cut back investment, we'll obviously be prudent given that you will see a decline in gross margins next year, but we're not going to be cutting back investment because we expect to return to growth quickly, so you'll see us, not, let's say cut back, but certainly put more behind this business to drive that long-term growth that we do expect to be industry leading over the long-term.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Robert A. Michael", "section_number": 44, "uuid": "c134d464-8303-4e5d-aaee-093b8fc82f8c", "speaker_title": "Vice Chairman and President at AbbVie"}

section.text: Thanks Gary. Operator, next question please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Shea", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "299d33c1-fc54-4081-8e0f-c8bb034ad528", "speaker_title": "Vice President, Investor Relations at AbbVie"}

section.text: Hey, good morning. Thanks for taking the questions. So, first on CF, you recently posted an update ClinTrials for your new C2 corrector-based regimen. Just wondering if you could walk us through what gives you confidence that this has a higher probability of success versus your last iteration? And then second one for, Rick, just wanted to touch base on your succession plans, been an increasingly sort of important and frequent topic with investors, you've been the architect of AbbVie's success infection, and so just wanted to confirm specifically how long you expect to stay in the seat, and then how should we think about the timelines around the process to identify on your successor? Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Colin Bristow", "section_number": 47, "uuid": "63de0894-c903-4c68-b00d-dac3118c085b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at UBS"}

section.text: Yeah, this is Tom, I'll answer the CF question. Again, this is very challenging to actually make that abnormal CF protein get to the membrane and act as chloride channel and it takes three different drugs to make it effectively to get it to the cell membrane and open up in the right way, and so we felt that we had -- and so we call them corrector 1, corrector 2 and potentiator, these three different compounds. We always see good results with double, our C1 corrector, we think is best-in-class or potentially that is very good, what we have had difficulties to get a good C2 corrector and what I presented earlier this year was that it wasn't good enough, but what we've done since then, we will continue to look at better ones and we came out with differentiated product 576 which is structurally different and the data supports higher safety margin, higher exposures, good PK, hopefully a single pill. And then, we'd be able to get to this -- to able to have this triplet which is really important to be competitive. So again, our doublet, the data we had was very strong, but we needed that third piece, and that third piece seems to be coming out really well, that's what we really saw on the website at CT.gov is moving to evaluate this triple combo with our new C2 corrector.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas J. Hudson", "section_number": 48, "uuid": "0f82c84f-292a-4ccb-9901-1dbb88b0edf0", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President, R&D, and Chief Scientific Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: And this is Rick. On the succession question. I'd say that we obviously have a very experienced Board, and we've had an active approach on succession going back to about 2016-2017. And that process has proceeded extremely well in developing internal candidates to ultimately assume the role when I do retire. I can tell you that there are no plans at all for me to retire in 2023. The most important thing to me and to the Board is to make sure that the business is performing exactly as we expect going forward and we're not going to make any transition until we've gone through the biosimilar event, and we're confident in the performance of the overall business. That would be the appropriate time once we're confident to make a transition at that point. We've also had discussions with the Board of what that transition would look like, and assuming it's an internal candidate, the transition will essentially work where we will name a new CEO, and at that point, I will assume the role of Executive Chair for a period of time thereafter. So, I think we have a well-thought-out succession approach. I feel very comfortable with the approach, I feel comfortable with the work we're doing to develop the internal candidates, and I think the transition when it occurs, I think will go smoothly and be successful. So, hopefully that answers your question.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 49, "uuid": "2faf9b47-9b7e-4cde-93c9-e1adc1f7e487", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Thanks Colin. Operator, next question please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Shea", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "e5df1bc9-48ec-48dd-a33b-ca2bc348a4e1", "speaker_title": "Vice President, Investor Relations at AbbVie"}

section.text: Chris, you there? We can't hear you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Shea", "section_number": 52, "uuid": "c3f52eb4-91dc-444f-92b1-e6ddbbe15015", "speaker_title": "Vice President, Investor Relations at AbbVie"}

section.text: Yes, apologies. Two questions if I may. On Rinvoq, you have previously commented that you were seeing some news in the first-line setting, can you update us at all with any color there? Secondly, for Skyrizi, obviously a very attractive market and an opportunity in Crohn's disease, can you share with us how you're thinking about the potential impact given the LOE in 2023 of major branded player STELARA? Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chris Shibutani", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "ce2da30e-5b05-4d0c-a611-d17e7a8f9166", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Chris, its Jeff. Just to clarify in terms of your Rinvoq question was there a specific question related to a certain indication on the frontline, or I am not sure I fully appreciate that?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 55, "uuid": "35425b1c-8178-444d-b17c-b833dd8082d2", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Yes, no in AD.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chris Shibutani", "section_number": 56, "uuid": "39aeb6ab-c8db-4cc6-bb16-c7a4518eee42", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: In AD, okay. Right. So, yes we do see we do see frontline use across the globe and even in the U.S. and what we're seeing is now as I mentioned in my remarks, we're seeing in-line, in-play share which is in high mid-teens right now in the U.S. and it's higher in the international markets, so there seems to be, as we look to the research and we look to our end-market performance, there's really two segments of dermatologists, there's very cautious dermatologists that are slow to adopt JAKs, and typically they will start in the later line, or second-line plus. There is an emerging cohort of significant group of dermatologists as well that basically are looking at the underlying high efficacy parameters, so basically like the easy 90 skin clearance, and almost no discernible itch for the product. They typically are starting to use more and more in the frontline, so the overall balance is leaning towards the second line, but we do see increasing frontline utilization based on the profile of the drug in atopic dermatitis.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "211efa95-f5f1-4e57-ab03-f3513a51a59b", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: In terms of the Skyrizi for Crohn's, we think we're very, very well-positioned for a couple of reasons. One is the overall profile of the medicine is really exceptional as I've highlighted, and we're going to see very, very rapid adoption both in the U.S. and the external market. In addition, we have anticipated the STELARA LOE, we see that we have an ongoing head-to-head trial versus STELARA to make sure that we can continue to differentiate with direct data that will come over the next year or so. So, we are anticipating that, and we think we'll a good setup to maintain the early momentum that we're seeing with Skyrizi.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "211efa95-f5f1-4e57-ab03-f3513a51a59b", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Thanks Chris. Operator, next question please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Shea", "section_number": 58, "uuid": "90a61d9b-c821-4ecc-8f93-c3778cf43c17", "speaker_title": "Vice President, Investor Relations at AbbVie"}

section.text: Hey, guys. Thanks so much for taking the question. I just had one quick one, Rick, whilst the questions on Humira for next year, but wanted to ask at a high-level on the environment beyond that. I know there are formal treatment guidelines and I&I, but what's the risk that payers mandate cycling through one or more biosimilars? And what's the risk that the pricing environment doesn't really recover in '24 and beyond, just obviously thinking about the Skyrizi and Rinvoq franchises over the long-term? Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Geoff Meacham", "section_number": 60, "uuid": "98e6645e-6dc5-49bd-a80b-51368ee337b1", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America"}

section.text: So, I'm actually going to have Jeff walk you through that, he is probably the closest to that environment.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "04566b62-c9c0-4d5c-b1d4-a69a2e6ff330", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Yeah, so, thank you for the question. I mean, one of the things that we see certainly in the near-term is that the formularies in I&I are actually expanding, so many years ago you might have six or seven preferred agents. The payers are now requesting sometimes up to 11 or 12 preferred agents, so you're seeing an expansive nature in the short-term. Now as you go-forward, maybe middle of the decade or later where you have more-and-more biosimilars, could the U.S. environment move towards sort of a step-through? I mean, it's possible, but we have again as I mentioned in my last statement, we have anticipated that with the right types of data, the trials, we have five head-to-head studies in Skyrizi in psoriasis, we have more coming in Crohn's and so we think that basically we have a data-driven approach that's going to continue to allow us to significantly differentiate our products.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 62, "uuid": "763009b6-aa60-4468-9685-1cb87305e0ac", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: The other dynamic that we watch very carefully, and we talked about this during the Immunology Investor Day is the lines of therapy as there is more-and-more, high-efficacy products that get introduced continue to expand. So, in the middle of the decade or longer, the second plus in the third line markets are going to be very, very significant at that point, so when we put all of that into the calculus, we feel again we have a pretty strong set-up for the middle of the decade and longer.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jeffrey R. Stewart", "section_number": 62, "uuid": "763009b6-aa60-4468-9685-1cb87305e0ac", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Commercial Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: This is Rick, I agree with everything Jeff said. The one thing I would add that as you think about even under a scenario where if we did get to some kind of a step at it, you have to go back and remember that most of these mechanisms, most patients fail, and they fail at a relatively high-level and over a relatively short period of time. So, even if you had to rotate through, you're going to get to second line relatively quickly, and recycling somebody back through another TNF typically doesn't work very well for those patients. And I'd say the demand now with kind of agents that we have on the market now and the level of remission that they can create, the demand among physicians is much higher to get patients into remission as rapidly as they possibly can. And so, I think all of those dynamics tell us that this model should continue to work over the long-haul.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Richard A. Gonzalez", "section_number": 63, "uuid": "03ef3674-054b-46ff-b542-31adc7ce9135", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at AbbVie"}

section.text: Thanks, Geoff. I believe we have taken all the questions in the queue. So that concludes today's conference call. If you'd like to listen to a replay of the call, please visit our website at investors.abbvie.com. Thanks again for joining us.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Shea", "section_number": 64, "uuid": "7e695f5d-01cf-46f0-93ad-770fb95049d8", "speaker_title": "Vice President, Investor Relations at AbbVie"}

title: Q&A for ABBV (AbbVie) on 10/28/22 9:00 AM ET
